title: How is the concept of assimilation related to the symbolism of agriculture and the relationship between the body and the soul?
first_phrase: In this text, the concept of assimilation is explored through its parallel in Hebrew where adamah means earth and adam means man. The explicit identification between body and earth is made by two ancient Latin writers, Ennio and Varrone. Varrone explains that the body consists of humid and cold elements, which are the earth, while the soul essence is warmth or heaven. In the last 200 tokens, Varrone continues to explain the separation of the soul from the body as the exit from life, which is also referred to as "exitus" or death. Ennio further emphasizes that the earth, or the body, takes from the soul without losing any essence.
content: Quindi Varrone (De 1. l., v, 60) scrive: « ragione Pacuvio che dice: Animam aether adjugat (l'ete re accoppia l'anima) »; ed Ennio: « Terrori corpus quae dederit, ipsam capere, neque dispendi lacere hilum » (La terra stessa ossia il corpo prende ciò che [l'anima] le diede, né con ciò fa la menoma perdita). « La separa * zione — prosegue Varrone (De 1. L, v, 60) — dell'anima * dal corpo è per gli esseri viventi un'uscita dalla vita, * exitus; come si chiama la morte exitum (cfr. ital. esi * ziale) e la nascita initia perché il corpo e l'anima in * unum ineunt ».
last_phrase: In conclusion, Varrone and Ennio utilize the symbolism of agriculture to convey a spiritual and even initiatory meaning to the separation of the soul from the body. By likening the body to the soil that receives the seed of the soul, they suggest that the material world becomes the mother of the spiritual world. Together with Macrobio's insights on the Saturnalia, these passages provide confirmation of the existence and continuity of a Roman initiatory tradition that derives from the primordial tradition of the Golden Age.
